title: Gujarati Cuisine
hero_image_alt: Grand Gujarati Thali with Dhokla and Farsan
short_description: Predominantly vegetarian, balancing sweet, salty, and spicy flavors. Famous for its elaborate Thalis and snacks (Farsan).
long_description:
Gujarati cuisine is one of the oldest culinary treasures of India and is primarily vegetarian, though some communities (like the Bohras) eat meat. It is unique for its extensive use of sugar or jaggery in almost all dishes, creating a subtle sweet-salty-spicy balance. The cuisine changes proportionally with the region: Kathiawar (spicy), Surat (sweet/salty), and Kutch (simple).

The typical Gujarati meal is a 'Thali'—a large silver platter consisting of Rotli (bread), Dal or Kadhi (yogurt soup), Rice (Bhat), and 'Shaak/Sabzi' (vegetable curries). A distinguishing feature is 'Farsan' (steamed or fried snacks) served alongside the meal. Gujarati food is also known for being low on oil but high on flavor, often tempered with mustard seeds, cumin, and curry leaves.

signature_dishes.name: Dhokla
signature_dishes.short_description: Steamed savory cake made from fermented rice and chickpea batter, tempered with mustard seeds and curry leaves.

signature_dishes.name: Undhiyu
signature_dishes.short_description: A mixed vegetable casserole made with winter greens, tubers, and fenugreek dumplings, traditionally cooked upside down in earthen pots.

signature_dishes.name: Gujarati Kadhi
signature_dishes.short_description: A sweet and tangy yogurt-based curry thickened with gram flour and tempered with spices.

signature_dishes.name: Thepla
signature_dishes.short_description: Spiced flatbread made from whole wheat flour and fenugreek leaves (methi), known for its long shelf life.

top_restaurants.name: Agashiye
top_restaurants.notes: Heritage rooftop restaurant serving a premium Gujarati Thali experience.

top_restaurants.name: Gordhan Thal
top_restaurants.notes: Famous for its unlimited Thali with a huge variety of dishes.

top_restaurants.name: Sasuma
top_restaurants.notes: Renowned for authentic Surti food and hospitality.

street_food_highlights: Khandvi - Rolled, spiced gram flour bite-sized snacks.
Fafda Jalebi - A popular breakfast combo of crisp savory straws and sweet pretzels.
Dabeli - Spicy potato burger originating from Kutch.
recommended_precautions_for_travellers: Food is sweeter than typical Indian curry; be prepared for sugar in savory dishes.
how_to_order_guidelines: Order an 'Unlimited Thali' for the full experience. The servers will keep refilling until you stop them.
cultural_significance: Ahimsa (non-violence) deeply influences the diet (mostly vegetarian). Jain food (no onion/garlic) is also widely available.
dining_etiquette: Wash hands. Food is often served by the host with great insistence ('Agrah').

top_places_to_experience.title: Ahmedabad
top_places_to_experience.summary: India's first UNESCO Heritage City, famous for its street food and Thalis.

top_places_to_experience.title: Surat
top_places_to_experience.summary: The food capital of Gujarat, known its bakery products and unique snacks like Locho.

top_places_to_experience.title: Vadodara
top_places_to_experience.summary: Cultural capital with a mix of traditional Kathiawadi and modern fusion food.

suggested_itineraries: Gujarat Thali Trail: Ahmedabad (Agashiye) -> Vadodara (Kathiawadi) -> Surat (Undhiyu).
